Input.threadtitle: Are the goals in your organization clearly communicated?
Input.posts:
In one company that I worked I was part of the Senior Team, as part of that team we felt that we had set out clear goals and direction for the company. Our staff were very mobile, with the over 80% working full time on our customers premises, therefore our day to day contact with them was very limited. We decided to test how clear our goals and company direction had filtered out through the companies structure to the various staff, by means of a staff survey. We were horrified to discover that less than 20% of the staff felt they had a clear understanding of the companies goals and direction, and less than 10% knew what their role contributed to them. Do you know your companies goals? If we asked a random number of participants how closely would their answers match?

Instructor's Post
Great to see huge interest on this thread. I wish to add some clarity on this subject on 'goals in your organization' that I found rather broad. I hope this may add value to the discussions. Typically, in an organization, goals can be grouped into two primary goal categories: a) Organizational Goals (we lerned in Lecture 1), i.e., Mission/VIsion Statements that may include its strategies, and, b) Business or Operational Goals. I think everyone can figure out the context of the two types of goals and its differences. However, I must admit the description and definition may vary from organization to organization and subject to cultural norms. I think clarity on an employee's work and delivery performance must be based on clear KPIs in key result areas (KRA). Clear communication on tasks and responsibilities in their functional role lies on the immediate manager or supervisor on a periodical basis for new staff, and, at least once a year for others. Leaders should practice MBWA. After all, 'in unity there is strength' . There were many feedback concerning the problem on communicating goals across the organization structure especially to the 'factory-floor' or 'floor-shop' layer in an organization. We have to assume employees in an organization cares and are interested in how and where the organization is heading because their jobs and careers is dependent on the success of the organization, right? Using the Organizational Process Model and applying Logic of Appropriateness, we may be able as, OA analyst, identify the root of organizational problems and make recommendation to remedy the problem.

Great to see huge interest on this thread. I wish to add some clarity on this subject on 'goals in your organization' that I found rather broad. I hope this may add value to the discussions. Typically, in an organization, goals can be grouped into two primary goal categories: a) Organizational Goals (we lerned in Lecture 1), i.e., Mission/VIsion Statements that may include its strategies, and, b) Business or Operational Goals. I think clarity on an employee's work and delivery performance must be based on clear KPIs in key result areas (KRA). Clear communication on tasks and responsibilities in their functional role lies on the immediate manager or supervisor on a periodical basis for new staff, and, at least once a year for others. Leaders should practice MBWA. After all, 'in unity there is strength' . There were many feedback concerning the problem on communicating goals across the organization structure especially to the 'factory-floor' or 'floor-shop' layer in an organization. We have to assume employees in an organization cares and are interested in how and where the organization is heading because their jobs and careers is dependent on the success of the organization, right? Input.threadtitle: Are the goals in your organization clearly communicated?
Input.posts:
In one company that I worked I was part of the Senior Team, as part of that team we felt that we had set out clear goals and direction for the company. Our staff were very mobile, with the over 80% working full time on our customers premises, therefore our day to day contact with them was very limited. We decided to test how clear our goals and company direction had filtered out through the companies structure to the various staff, by means of a staff survey. We were horrified to discover that less than 20% of the staff felt they had a clear understanding of the companies goals and direction, and less than 10% knew what their role contributed to them. Do you know your companies goals? If we asked a random number of participants how closely would their answers match?

Great to see huge interest on this thread. I wish to add some clarity on this subject on 'goals in your organization' that I found rather broad. I hope this may add value to the discussions. Typically, in an organization, goals can be grouped into two primary goal categories: a) Organizational Goals (we lerned in Lecture 1), i.e., Mission/VIsion Statements that may include its strategies, and, b) Business or Operational Goals. However, I must admit the description and definition may vary from organization to organization and subject to cultural norms. I think clarity on an employee's work and delivery performance must be based on clear KPIs in key result areas (KRA). Clear communication on tasks and responsibilities in their functional role lies on the immediate manager or supervisor on a periodical basis for new staff, and, at least once a year for others. Leaders should practice MBWA. After all, 'in unity there is strength' . In one company that I worked I was part of the Senior Team, as part of that team we felt that we had set out clear goals and direction for the company. Our staff were very mobile, with the over 80% working full time on our customers premises, therefore our day to day contact with them was very limited. We decided to test how clear our goals and company direction had filtered out through the companies structure to the various staff, by means of a staff survey. We were horrified to discover that less than 20% of the staff felt they had a clear understanding of the companies goals and direction, and less than 10% knew what their role contributed to them. Do you know your companies goals? If we asked a random number of participants how closely would their answers match?

In one company that I worked I was part of the Senior Team, as part of that team we felt that we had set out clear goals and direction for the company. Our staff were very mobile, with the over 80% working full time on our customers premises, therefore our day to day contact with them was very limited. We decided to test how clear our goals and company direction had filtered out through the companies structure to the various staff, by means of a staff survey. We were horrified to discover that less than 20% of the staff felt they had a clear understanding of the companies goals and direction, and less than 10% knew what their role contributed to them. Do you know your companies goals? If we asked a random number of participants how closely would their answers match?

Great to see huge interest on this thread. I wish to add some clarity on this subject on 'goals in your organization' that I found rather broad. I hope this may add value to the discussions. Typically, in an organization, goals can be grouped into two primary goal categories: a) Organizational Goals (we lerned in Lecture 1), i.e., Mission/VIsion Statements that may include its strategies, and, b) Business or Operational Goals. I think everyone can figure out the context of the two types of goals and its differences. However, I must admit the description and definition may vary from organization to organization and subject to cultural norms. I think clarity on an employee's work and delivery performance must be based on clear KPIs in key result areas (KRA). Clear communication on tasks and responsibilities in their functional role lies on the immediate manager or supervisor on a periodical basis for new staff, and, at least once a year for others. Leaders should practice MBWA. After all, 'in unity there is strength' . There were many feedback concerning the problem on communicating goals across the organization structure especially to the 'factory-floor' or 'floor-shop' layer in an organization. We have to assume employees in an organization cares and are interested in how and where the organization is heading because their jobs and careers is dependent on the success of the organization, right? Using the Organizational Process Model and applying Logic of Appropriateness, we may be able as, OA analyst, identify the root of organizational problems and make recommendation to remedy the problem.

Input.threadtitle: Are the goals in your organization clearly communicated?
Input.posts:
In one company that I worked I was part of the Senior Team, as part of that team we felt that we had set out clear goals and direction for the company. Our staff were very mobile, with the over 80% working full time on our customers premises, therefore our day to day contact with them was very limited. We decided to test how clear our goals and company direction had filtered out through the companies structure to the various staff, by means of a staff survey. We were horrified to discover that less than 20% of the staff felt they had a clear understanding of the companies goals and direction, and less than 10% knew what their role contributed to them. Do you know your companies goals? If we asked a random number of participants how closely would their answers match?

When we use the different frameworks to understand the case studies, such as the Chicago Public School system, where do we account for corruption in understanding the impact on organizational decisions? Corruption is endemic in Chicago and in such a way that is not just a one-off but has rules and relationships that govern it. This is true in some governments as well. Corruption is interwoven in an organization. There are factors to it such as who occupies a particular role, their family and network, and their alliances. There are also rules associated with corruption that can directly contradict the stated mission and vision of an organization. And while corruption can be endemic in an organization, it often runs counter to the organization. Roads are not built, schools are not improved, as money is syphoned off to actors within the organization.

Input.threadtitle: How does systematic corruption fit in the picture?
Input.posts:
When we use the different frameworks to understand the case studies, such as the Chicago Public School system, where do we account for corruption in understanding the impact on organizational decisions? Corruption is endemic in Chicago and in such a way that is not just a one-off but has rules and relationships that govern it. This is true in some governments as well. Corruption is interwoven in an organization. There are factors to it such as who occupies a particular role, their family and network, and their alliances. There are also rules associated with corruption that can directly contradict the stated mission and vision of an organization. And while corruption can be endemic in an organization, it often runs counter to the organization. Roads are not built, schools are not improved, as money is syphoned off to actors within the organization.

Input.threadtitle: Organizational Analysis Applied to Organized Criminal Enterprises and Terrorist Organizations
Input.posts:
Greetings, I hope you're all well. I have learned a great deal from the many of you who have more of a background in businesses as organizations. You've already transformed the way I interpret the world (whether I am reading a newspaper article, a non-fiction book, blog post, or watching/listening to some news headline, or reflecting on my past studies (undergrad) in Communication). I would like to get your input on organizational theories applied to terrorist organizations or organized criminal enterprises and how organizational analysis could help improve our understandings of these groups and, as a result, better predict ways to add to our 'intelligence' and our ability to better 'compete' with them. For example, intelligence agencies/organizations or law enforcement groups/organizations have special units tasked with, essentially, dismantling or weakening these criminal/terrorist organizations. Intelligence is gathered and decisions are made via appropriate analysis of the various elements of the criminal/terrorist organizations. In your opinion, focusing on what elements of a criminal/terrorist organization would be most beneficial in dismantling/weakening the organization? Or are all organizational elements important in analyzing said organizations for weaknesses? Also, is analysis of our intelligence agencies/orgs and law enforcement groups/orgs leading to reform/bettering of our agencies equally or more important than analysis of 'enemy'/'competing' (terrorist/crime organizations) looking for weaknesses to exploit? Or, do you think a combination analyzing and reforming our intelligence community organizations and analyzing the criminal/terrorist organizations we are attempting to disable (or reform into non-violent organizations) would be the most successful approach to reaching our goals. (Ie focus reform internally or externally; or improving our organizations or weakening competitors' organizations; or, do both tend to occur at once/have some sort of correlation or causation relationship?) In writing such a broad but basic question, I myself am in awe of just how abundant organizations are and how much one move by one group of participants or one change in one organizations environment could wind up having a powerful domino-like effect on other organizations, worldwide. The layers, scales, focus points and interactions fascinate me, which is why I'd love to get your varying input on intelligence/national (or world) security reform, as we progress through the course and address different theories! Thank you so much for taking the time to read this lengthy post and please know how much I value your input! Best, Tara
